translation.en: And it turns out, the more we learn and understand about our psychology,

translation.ko: 뇌가 우릴 속이려 한다는 걸 더 분명히 깨닫게 되죠

translation.en: Generally speaking, things in the material world

translation.ko: 철저한 알고리듬으로 돌아가는데요 X라는 결과를 내려면 A, B, C를 거쳐야 해요

translation.ko: X라는 결과를 내려면 A, B, C를 거쳐야 해요

and then you follow the steps, and the thing happens.
translation.ko: 그 단계들을 따른 다음 결과를 얻게 되는데

is in the experiences of our own mind.
translation.ko: 그 알고리듬이 통하지 않는 영역이 바로 마음속 경험이죠

There's no formula for happiness. There's no X, Y, Z.
Do these things every day for three weeks and you'll be happy.
Right? Like, it doesn't work that way.
Happiness is not algorithmic.

But our mind plays this game with us.
translation.ko: 근데 마음은 우릴 속이며 이렇게 설득해요

translation.ko: 근데 마음은 우릴 속이며 이렇게 설득해요 X를 얻는 즉시 만사가 잘 풀릴 테고

translation.ko: Y를 없애는 순간 다 괜찮아질 거라고요

translation.ko: 우리 앞에 늘 작은 당근이 매달려 있는 셈이죠

translation.ko: 새로운 책임이 생겨요 부하들 보고도 받고 주말에도 일해야 하니까요

translation.en: You're like, "Shit. If I could just get more vacation time,

translation.ko: 웬만해선 어딜 가도 만족할 수 없어요

translation.ko: 그럼 인스타그램에 뜬 데로 휴가를 떠나고 싶죠

translation.ko: 계속해서 우리 눈앞에 보상을 매달아 흔들며

translation.en: convincing us that if we can just take that next step, then we'll live happily ever after.
translation.ko: 다음 단계만 거치면 평생 행복할 거라 설득하죠

translation.en: Psychologists call this the hedonic treadmill.

translation.ko: 기분이 좋아질 만한 일을 해내려 하는데요

translation.en: to… to dissolve our suffering, to dissolve our… our dissatisfaction permanently,
translation.ko: 고통과 불만을 영영 해소할 수 있다는 건

translation.en: I… It's just bullshit.

translation.ko: 행복이 좋긴 해도 따분한 면이 있죠

translation.en: because it's when you're happy, it means nothing needs to change.
translation.ko: 행복하다는 건 변화가 필요 없다는 뜻이잖아요

translation.en: And so, I think it's important to learn how to sit with your negative emotions,
translation.ko: 그래서 부정적인 감정도 참고 견디는 게 중요하다고 봐요

translation.en: because it… it's like cross-training for your mind.
translation.ko: 그럼 여러모로 마음을 단련할 수 있거든요

translation.en: You know, you're always… everything you try to do in your life,
you're gonna bump up against challenges, setbacks.
You know, people are gonna do awful things to you, accidents are gonna happen,
translation.ko: 사람들이 몹쓸 짓을 하고 사고도 나는데

translation.en: and so the more you're willing to sit with those feelings,
translation.ko: 그런 부정적인 감정을 참아 내려는 의지가 강할수록

translation.en: the more prepared you're gonna be in the moment, when something goes wrong.

translation.en: And this is why I… I always say

translation.ko: 멀리 내다볼 때 스스로 해를 끼치는 거예요

translation.en: And this is why negative emotions are more interesting and useful

Because you can't always trust your positive emotions.

translation.en: I remember they got me out of… out of the… the jail,

translation.en: They told me I was never gonna go back to that school again.
translation.ko: 다신 학교에도 못 나갈 거라고 하셨어요

translation.en: Essentially, I mean, for a 13-year-old, that's… that's basically like telling you your life's over.
translation.ko: 13살짜리에게 그 말은 인생이 끝났다는 거나 다름없죠

translation.en: So, I lost my friends,
lost my school, lost my legal rights.
And then three months later, my parents got divorced.
And so my family fell apart.
And so in the span of about six months,
everything I understood about my life and who I was…
collapsed at roughly the same time.
Like, just everything went to shit at the same time.
From that point, you know, there was a deep, deep sense of hurt.
translation.ko: 그런 면에서 아주 깊은 상처를 받았어요

translation.en: I went to basically being a lonely kid with no friends, no family.
translation.ko: 친구도 가족도 없는 외톨이 소년이 됐으니까요

translation.en: A lot of the other guys start picking on me, you know, beating me up.
translation.ko: 다른 남자애들이 절 괴롭히며 패기 시작했죠

translation.en: And I spent the vast majority of my time
getting high, playing video games, playing music,
translation.ko: 마약에 취해 비디오 게임과 음악을 즐기며

translation.en: basically being on my own.
People would come over and just…
sit with me and talk, like, it was like I wasn't there, you know.
translation.ko: 옆에 앉아 말을 걸어도 전 그 자리에 없었어요

translation.en: It was like there was this meat robot that was, like…
pretending to be Mark, but Mark was somewhere else.
translation.ko: 마크인 척할 뿐 진짜 마크는 딴 데 있었죠

translation.en: I had a lot of social anxiety.
I used to think to myself, "Man, I wish I knew how to talk to people."
translation.ko: 속으로 이런 생각도 했죠 '대화하는 법을 알면 좋을 텐데'

translation.en: I had so many completely irrational beliefs…
translation.ko: 너무나 비이성적인 신념도 잔뜩 품고 있었어요

translation.en: about how the world worked.
I had trouble believing and trusting that people actually liked me
translation.ko: 남들이 진심으로 절 좋아해서 함께 어울리려 한다는 걸

translation.en: or were interested in hanging out with me.
But because I was unaware that I had created this prison for myself,
translation.ko: 그 감옥을 제가 만들었다는 걸 미처 깨닫지 못했기에

translation.en: I just felt very helpless.
I became this, like, very insecure, kind of…
strangely meek guy…
with a sense that something is fundamentally wrong with me,
but that I'm somehow at the center of the Universe.
translation.ko: 왠지 제가 우주의 중심인 것만 같았죠

translation.en: I once knew this guy named Jimmy.
Jimmy was a real go-getter.
Here we are. Welcome home, baby.
-[camera shutter clicking] -[Mark] He seemed to always know these incredible people in powerful places, you know.
translation.ko: 어딜 가나 입김이 센 멋진 지인들이 있더라고요

translation.en: He always had business ventures going, trying to find some new angle.
translation.ko: 늘 사업을 추진하고 새로운 시각을 찾고

translation.en: Always onto the latest new thing.
He was a super-positive guy, a lot of fun to be around.
Great dude to party with.
Mmm. She's tasty to arrive in.
Like the guy was just always on.
I want you to remember this moment. Don't forget this fucking moment.
translation.ko: 이 순간을 기억해 절대 잊지 말란 말이야

translation.en: [Mark] He seemed to completely lack the insecurities that I had so much of.
translation.ko: 제 안에 가득한 불안 따위는 전혀 없는 눈치였어요

translation.en: And for a while, that was an incredibly empowering thing to be around.
translation.ko: 한동안 그 친구의 영향으로 큰 힘을 얻기도 했죠

translation.en: He and I had a lot of fun.
The problem was is that he was a total fraud.
Like, just… full stop, hundred percent fraud, top to bottom.
He would do things like talk companies into bringing him on as an angel investor,
translation.ko: 본인을 에인절 투자자로 모시라며 기업들을 설득하고

translation.en: you know, and giving him advisor equity
because of all these other start-ups he'd supposedly worked for.
But he hadn't actually worked for any of those start-ups,
translation.ko: 근데 실제로 스타트업을 도운 적은 없었고

translation.en: and he didn't actually have any expertise.
He just talked his way into it.
Next thing you know, these people have given a percentage of their business to this guy.
translation.ko: 거기에 넘어간 사람들이 자기 회사 지분까지 넘겨줬고요

translation.en: He never shows up for work and never does anything.
translation.ko: 지미는 출근도 안 하고 하는 일도 없어요

translation.en: You know, there was always some great business idea that was gonna take off.
It was gonna be the next Uber, or the next Facebook, whatever.
And no, he was just, you know, picking up some girl,
translation.ko: 근데 지미는 여자나 꼬시고 레스토랑으로 데려가서

translation.en: and taking her to some restaurant, and spending 1,000 dollars on dinner.
translation.ko: 근데 지미는 여자나 꼬시고 레스토랑으로 데려가서 천 달러짜리 저녁이나 먹었죠

translation.en: So, the question is, is Jimmy a successful guy?
Is he happy?
On paper, he's… he's everything that we consider successful.
translation.ko: 겉으로만 보면 성공의 모든 조건을 갖췄죠

translation.en: But on a moral metric, he's a disaster.
translation.ko: 근데 도덕적으로 따져 보면 구제 불능이에요

translation.en: So, how did this happen?
You know, back in the 1970s,
self-esteem kind of became all the rage in psychology.
There were a number of studies that were done in the '60s
that found that, generally, kids who felt better about themselves…
translation.ko: 1960년대의 여러 연구를 보면 일반적으로 자존감이 높은 아이들은

translation.en: got better grades in school,
got better jobs after school, made more money, committed less crime.
translation.ko: 더 좋은 직장을 얻어서 소득도 높고 범죄율은 낮았죠

translation.en: Self-esteem kind of… it became celebrated as this, like, panacea for all the social ills.
translation.ko: 자존감은 모든 사회악의 만병통치약 취급을 받았어요

translation.en: Like, we just need people to feel good about themselves.
And then everything else will take care of itself.
translation.ko: 다른 모든 문제는 저절로 해결된다는 거죠

translation.en: And so, this is when you start getting grade inflation in schools,
you start getting participation trophies in sports,
you start getting parents telling their little Timmy and little Susie
translation.ko: 부모들은 어린 자식들한테 이렇게 말하기 시작했죠

translation.en: that, "You can be whatever you wanna be.
translation.ko: '넌 어떤 꿈이든 이룰 수 있고 지금 그대로도 멋져'

translation.en: You're… you're brilliant as you are. Don't let anybody tell you otherwise."
translation.ko: '넌 어떤 꿈이든 이룰 수 있고 지금 그대로도 멋져' '누구도 그걸 부정할 수 없지'

translation.en: And a whole of generation of teachers and parents and leaders did this,
translation.ko: 한 세대의 교사, 부모와 지도자가 그런 식으로 행동하면서

translation.en: believing that they were raising
kind of this psychologically elite generation of people
who were gonna feel great, and do amazing things in the world.
translation.ko: 넘치는 자신감으로 멋진 일을 해내리라 믿었죠

translation.en: But then you jump 20 years later, and the data came in.
And it turns out that raising people's self-esteem,
it doesn't create a generation of Bill Gates and Martin Luther King Juniors.
translation.ko: 빌 게이츠나 마틴 루서 킹 주니어 같은 세대가 탄생하진 않았어요

translation.en: It creates a generation of Jimmys.
Jimmy was always positive.
Jimmy always felt great about himself.
Jimmy always thought he deserved whatever he got.
And that's insane. [laughs] That's…
Society cannot function if everybody is like that,
if everybody believes they have a right to take more than they give.
translation.ko: 베푸는 것 이상으로 누려야 한다고 다들 믿는다면요

translation.en: Jimmy is entitled.
And entitlement,
it's when you feel as though you deserve the benefits of something
without giving up the cost of something.
translation.ko: 본인은 비용을 들일 필요 없이 어떤 혜택을 누릴 자격이 있다고 느끼는 거예요

translation.en: When you feel like you should have the results without having the sacrifice.
translation.ko: 본인이 희생 없이 결과를 누려야 한다는 거죠

translation.en: You know, Jimmy's problem was that he thought
translation.ko: 지미의 문제는 자기가 끝내주는 성공을 누려야 한다고 여겼다는 거예요

translation.en: he should be a total badass and a huge success,
translation.ko: 자기가 끝내주는 성공을 누려야 한다고 여겼다는 거예요

translation.en: without actually putting the work in, without actually doing anything.
translation.ko: 실제로 노력하거나 손 하나 까딱하지 않고서요

translation.en: Fundamentally, entitlement is a way to protect ourselves.
It's a delusional belief to remove you from the reality of yourself,
translation.ko: 자기 현실과 거리를 두기 위한 망상에 가까운 믿음이죠

translation.en: the reality that life is fucking painful,
you're limited, and no matter what you do,
translation.ko: 본인의 능력도 부족해서 뭘 해도 달라지지 않거든요

translation.en: it's always gonna be that way.
And so, when that is too painful for us to accept,
translation.ko: 그런 현실을 인정하는 게 너무 고통스러우면

translation.en: we… we create these delusional beliefs
that somehow we're special, we're unique,
we deserve special treatment.
That our problems are problems that nobody else can understand.
translation.ko: 특별 대우를 받을 자격이 있고 아무도 이해할 수 없는 문제를 안고 있으며

translation.en: That our talents are talents that nobody else can understand.
translation.ko: 아무도 이해하지 못할 재능도 가지고 있고

translation.en: That it's the world that's holding us back.
That we would be great and everything would be perfect
translation.ko: 모든 게 완벽해져서 내가 잘 살기 위해서는

translation.en: if it wasn't for… for that guy or that group or that situation.
translation.ko: 그 사람이나 그 단체나 그 상황만 없으면 되는 줄 알아요

translation.en: It's a protective layer for ourselves because it… it prevents us
translation.ko: 그런 믿음은 우릴 지키는 보호막이죠 우리가 극심한 고통의 순간으로 돌아가지 않게 막아 주니까요

translation.en: from returning to that point of that intense pain.
translation.ko: 우리가 극심한 고통의 순간으로 돌아가지 않게 막아 주니까요

translation.en: It's like a circuit breaker goes off in our brain and-and we almost…
translation.ko: 마치 뇌의 회로 차단기가 내려가는 셈인데

translation.en: like, we have to escape it, you know. We-we have to find an exit route.
translation.ko: 우린 거기서 벗어나야 해요 출구를 찾아야만 하죠

translation.en: You know, I didn't… I never knew Jimmy well enough
to figure out what had gone on in his life to make him that way.
translation.ko: 어떤 삶을 살았기에 그렇게 됐는지는 모르겠네요

translation.en: But, like, you're talking about a guy, like,
he didn't seem to even understand the notion of friendship or trust.
translation.ko: 우정이나 신뢰의 개념조차 이해 못 하는 눈치였어요

translation.en: Like, trust to him, like, seemed like a… a… like a way to get fucked over, you know.
And so, it just makes you wonder, like,
what in his background hurt him so badly to make him protect himself?
translation.ko: 그동안 어떤 상처를 받았길래 그토록 자기를 방어하게 됐을까요?

translation.en: But, like, to me, it was incredibly validating to have somebody like that, you know.
translation.ko: 그래도 그런 지인을 둔 덕에 확실히 깨닫게 됐죠

translation.en: I can be that guy who's saying whatever the fuck he wants,
translation.ko: 저 역시 뭐든 마음대로 지껄일 수 있고

translation.en: I'm that guy who can walk up to any girl he wants.
translation.ko: 원하면 어느 여자한테나 접근할 수 있다고요

translation.en: Like, just completely shattered everything I knew about life in reality.
translation.ko: 제가 알던 현실적인 삶의 개념이 모조리 산산조각 난 거죠

translation.en: Entitlement is… It's easy to fall into because it… it feels good.
translation.ko: 특권 의식에 빠져들기는 쉬워요 그럼 기분 좋거든요

translation.en: It's satisfying, in a… in a weird sort of way.
You know, like, we all…
We like the idea that we're somehow the exception in the world, you know?
Like, we-we like the idea that…
our problems are somehow unique or insurmountable,
translation.ko: 우리가 겪는 문제는 독특해서 해결할 수 없다고요

translation.en: because it-it suggests that there's something… uniquely meaningful about our own existence.
translation.ko: 그럼 우리 존재가 남달리 중요하다는 뜻이니까요

translation.en: We're constantly allured by this message
that we are somehow deserving of everything that we desire.
translation.ko: 우린 끊임없이 그러한 메시지에 홀려서 원하는 걸 전부 누릴 자격이 있다고 생각해요

translation.en: You know, there's not a conspiracy theory, it's not, like, a nefarious plan.
translation.ko: 이건 음모론도 아니고 사악한 계략도 아니에요

translation.en: It's just, I think, when that happens to be what wins people's attention,
translation.ko: 단지 그러한 메시지가 사람들의 관심을 끌고

translation.en: and you've built an economy off of monetizing people's attention,
translation.ko: 그 관심을 돈벌이로 삼아 경제를 구축하면

translation.en: you end up with a culture that is largely built on the message of entitlement.
translation.ko: 특권 의식을 바탕으로 한 문화가 생기기 마련이라는 거죠

translation.en: Traditional self-help says that every single person is special and unique
translation.ko: 전통적인 자조 사상은 모든 사람이 특별하고 독특하며 비범해질 수 있다는 건데요

translation.en: and can be extraordinary and I… [chuckles]
translation.ko: 모든 사람이 특별하고 독특하며 비범해질 수 있다는 건데요

translation.en: …I find that tyrannical, like, I find that to be a very confining idea,
translation.ko: 전 그게 독단적이고 굉장히 편협한 사상 같아요

translation.en: 'cause it promotes entitlement in people.
I think what's actually very liberating is recognizing that
translation.ko: 진정한 해방감을 느끼려면 그 누구도 특별하지 않다는 걸 깨달아야 한다고 봐요

translation.en: none of us are very special.
translation.ko: 그 누구도 특별하지 않다는 걸 깨달아야 한다고 봐요

translation.en: We're all very mundane, we all deal with the same problems,
translation.ko: 다들 지극히 평범하고 똑같은 문제와 씨름하며

translation.en: we all suffer in very similar ways to each other.
But the problem is that with social media and the internet,
we are constantly exposed
to the top 0.0001 percent of performers in everything.
translation.ko: 모든 면에서 상위 0.0001%인 특출난 이들을 접한다는 거예요

translation.en: [skydiver] And we are good to go.
If you think about most of our existence online
translation.ko: 온라인에서 보는 사람들이 어떤 모습인지 생각해 보면

translation.en: and what we're exposed to, I mean, it's…
translation.ko: 온라인에서 보는 사람들이 어떤 모습인지 생각해 보면 인스타그램에 접속했을 때는

translation.en: You go on Instagram and you're just greeted
by ridiculously good-looking people in ridiculously good-looking locations
translation.ko: 인스타그램에 접속했을 때는 말도 안 되게 멋진 사람들이 말도 안 되게 멋진 곳에서

translation.en: doing ridiculously awesome things…
translation.ko: 말도 안 되게 멋진 일을 하는 장면이 뜨죠

translation.en: pretty much 24/7.
And you go on Twitter and it seems like the fucking apocalypse has just started.
translation.ko: 트위터에 접속하면 마치 종말이 시작된 느낌이고요

translation.en: And then you go on Facebook and seemingly every single person is either getting married
translation.ko: 페이스북에 접속하면 마치 모든 사람이 한날한시에

translation.en: or having a kid at the exact same time.
This is the human highlight reel of social media.
translation.ko: 소셜 미디어로 보는 삶의 하이라이트 모음집이죠

translation.en: Yes!
Meanwhile, you're sitting in your fucking living room,
hand in your underwear, wondering what the fuck went wrong.
translation.ko: 속옷에 손을 찔러 넣은 채 대체 뭐가 문제였나 고민해요

translation.en: How did this happen? Why is my life so fucking mundane?
translation.ko: 어쩌다 이렇게 됐고 내 인생은 왜 이리 평범한지요

translation.en: And it's like… You feel like a loser.
But there's no reason to, because that's what everybody's life looks like.
translation.ko: 그렇게 느낄 필요는 없어요 다들 그렇게 살거든요

translation.en: We're all sitting in our living room with our hand in our underwear,
translation.ko: 다들 거실에 앉아 속옷에 손을 찔러 넣고서

translation.en: scrolling the exact same shit on our phones.
It's just, like, this is not reality.
There's all of these narratives out there that-that…
that kind of convince us that,
"Hey, you deserve to be this special guy or girl,
translation.ko: '야, 넌 특별한 사람이 될 자격이 있어'

translation.en: and if you can just embody that life, you'll be problem free.
translation.ko: '그 특별한 삶을 살기만 하면 모든 문제가 해결돼서'

translation.en: You won't have to deal with pain again. You won't have to sacrifice or struggle."
translation.ko: '다신 아픔을 겪거나 희생하고 고생할 필요 없어'

translation.en: And that's bullshit.
And look, the reason this message, like, "Life fucking sucks,
translation.ko: 반대로 이런 메시지도 있죠 '인생은 엉망진창이니 늘 희생과 고생이 따르고'

translation.en: you're always gonna have to sacrifice, you're always gonna struggle,
you're always gonna have problems."
The reason this… You don't hear this more is 'cause it doesn't sell.
translation.ko: 그런 메시지가 드문 건 그게 안 팔리기 때문이죠

translation.en: You can't sell a car by telling people, like, "Hey, buy this car.
translation.ko: 이렇게 말하면 차가 팔리겠어요? '여러분, 이 차를 사세요'

translation.en: You're still gonna be miserable, even though you bought it."
Like, that doesn't move merchandise, that doesn't help the bottom line.
translation.ko: 그럼 상품이 안 팔리고 매출도 안 오르겠죠

translation.en: And I don't think the problem is necessarily with, you know,
translation.ko: 하지만 꼭 자본주의나 사회 체제가 문제는 아니라고 봐요

translation.en: capitalism or the system or whatever, the problem is with us.
translation.ko: 하지만 꼭 자본주의나 사회 체제가 문제는 아니라고 봐요 우리가 문제죠

translation.en: Like, we just don't understand how our own minds work.
translation.ko: 우리 마음의 원리조차 이해 못 하니까요

translation.en: And so we've got to get straight with ourselves.
I think there's an undue psychological pressure
translation.ko: 우린 심리적으로 큰 압박에 시달리는 듯해요

translation.en: to feel as though we're extraordinary in some way, that we're doing something extraordinary.
translation.ko: 스스로 비범한 일을 하는 비범한 존재라고 느껴야만 하죠

translation.en: And I think this pushes a sense of entitlement,
it pushes a sense of, "Well, I deserve to have these things.
translation.ko: 이런 의식을 조장해요 '난 이걸 누리고 행복해질 자격이 있어'

translation.en: I deserve to be happy.

translation.ko: 냉전 시대 폴란드 출신으로 철의 장막 너머에 살았는데요

translation.en: And it's really interesting because if you look at the psychological research that was happening during the 20th century…

How do we make people feel better?
How do we improve people's self-esteem?
How do we make people happier?

translation.ko: 반면 동구에선 부정적 경험에 더 치중했죠

translation.en: It was about how does pain and suffering affect people?

translation.ko: 트라우마가 인격을 형성하거나 변화시키는 방식에 대해서요

translation.en: And Dą́browski, by being a researcher in Warsaw,

translation.ko: 2차 대전 및 홀로코스트 생존자를 연구할 기회가 있었는데요

translation.ko: 전쟁과 홀로코스트를 겪고 살아남은 사람 대부분이

translation.ko: 돌아보면 그런 경험에서 뭔가를 얻었다고 답한 거예요

translation.ko: 생존자들은 이렇게 말했죠 물론 그런 경험이 끔찍하긴 했어도

translation.ko: 그토록 끔찍한 일에 좋은 결과가 따를 수 있다니요

translation.ko: 이는 다이아몬드를 만드는 압력에 비유할 수 있을 겁니다

translation.ko: 인생에서 맛보는 긍정적 경험이 다 그렇듯

translation.ko: 누구나 재력과 끈끈한 인간관계를 원해요 다들 남에게 사랑받으며 인기를 누리고자 하고

translation.ko: 다들 남에게 사랑받으며 인기를 누리고자 하고 부자가 돼서 좋은 걸 갖고 싶고

translation.ko: 홍보하는 사람들은 변화가 파티처럼 즐겁다고 해요

translation.ko: 내가 선택한 고통이고 내가 선택한 고난이니

translation.ko: 그 선택 덕분에 고난마저 의미 있는 거예요

translation.ko: 저더러 해 보고 싶냐길래 전 주저하다가

translation.en: and I was like, "Uh… I might watch you first."
translation.ko: 저더러 해 보고 싶냐길래 전 주저하다가 그 친구가 뛰어내리는 것부터 구경하겠다고 했고요

translation.en: You know, like, that sort of thing.
translation.ko: 그 친구가 뛰어내리는 것부터 구경하겠다고 했고요

translation.en: And at some point during the party, I met… I met a girl and kind of got into her, and…
translation.ko: 전 파티를 즐기다가 어떤 여자애랑 가까워져서

translation.en: we got separated.
And the last time I ever saw Josh,
I was walking up towards the house… with the girl and he was coming down.
translation.ko: 전 여자애랑 콘도 쪽으로 올라가고 조시는 언덕을 내려왔어요

translation.en: And I said, "Hey, I'm gonna go get some food. Do you want some?
translation.ko: 제가 들어가서 뭐라도 같이 먹자고 했더니

translation.en: He was like, "No, man. I'm good. I'll catch you later."
And so, when I said, "Hey, where can I find you?",
he was like, "Seek the truth for yourself,
and I'll meet you there."
So, I just, like, laughed and, like, "All right, dude, whatever."
[chuckles] "I'll see you at the truth."
You know, as if we all know where the truth is.
translation.ko: 진리가 있는 데서 보자고요 진리가 어디 있는지 알지도 못하면서요

translation.en: And, uh… and so then, I went up to the house,
translation.ko: 그다음에 저랑 그 여자애는 콘도로 올라갔는데

translation.en: and then when we came out, everybody was gone.
And so it's, like, this weird, surreal, like, "What the fuck?" type moment.
translation.ko: 대체 무슨 상황인가 싶게 묘하고 비현실적인 순간이었죠

translation.en: And so we walked down to the water,
and I started looking for Josh and I can't find him.
There's, like, ambulances and police cars and stuff with the lights going,
and there were a couple of guys, like, in the water, swimming around.
And then I remember I walked up to, uh, this guy and this girl, and I asked them.
translation.ko: 어떤 남자랑 여자한테 가서 무슨 일인지 물어봤던 기억이 나요

translation.en: I'd seen them talking to Josh earlier, and I asked them.
And the girl just starts crying, like, just bawl…
Like as soon as I asked her, she just starts bawling.
And then at that point, I'm like, "Oh, my God.
It's him. Like, he's the one who went down."
And I must have walked around the water for, like, an hour, I guess.
translation.ko: 한 시간쯤 호숫가를 걸어 다녔던 것 같아요

translation.en: And… it just starts dawning on me, like, he's not here.
translation.ko: 그러다 조시가 떠났다는 걸 서서히 실감하게 됐죠

translation.en: I remember a police officer came up to me…
and asked me if I knew him and I said, "Yeah."
I don't remember what she asked, I don't remember…
I think she gave up.
I got in my car and I started driving back to Austin.
translation.ko: 제 차에 타서 오스틴으로 돌아가는 길에

translation.en: And so I called my dad. I was working for my dad that summer,
translation.ko: 아빠한테 전화했어요 그해 여름엔 아빠 일을 도왔는데

translation.en: and I called him and I was gonna tell him, like, "Hey, I'm… I'm not gonna make it to work today."
translation.ko: 그날은 출근 못 한다고 말씀드리려던 거죠

translation.en: And then I just fucking lost it.
I-I felt like a little boy…
crying to his father.
You know, it's like, you know, when you're like a little, little kid,
and you just grab your parent, and just like cry everything out into them.
Like, it was like that.
I've been depressed many times in my life, but, like, that was…
I've never, like, felt a bleakness.
Like, just a pure… nothingness.
I used to have dreams of him.
I remember I had this one dream…
where he and I were sitting in a jacuzzi together.
And I remember telling him,
"Hey, man, I'm… I'm really sorry you died."
[Mark] He was like… he's like, "Why do you care that I'm dead,
translation.ko: 조시가 그러더군요 '내가 죽은 게 무슨 상관인데?'

translation.en: when you're still so afraid to live?"
And I woke up from that dream just, like, a fucking mess, total mess.
translation.ko: 그 꿈에서 깨어났을 땐 제 꼴이 말도 아니었어요

translation.en: But I had this very powerful realization that,
if there's no reason to do anything,
there's also no reason to not do anything.
Like, there's no reason to be ashamed, there's no reason to be afraid.
And so that fall, I-I really…
it really changed me a lot.
You know, before he died, I was a very, like, prototypical…
translation.ko: 조시가 죽기 전의 저는 뻔하기 그지없는

translation.en: stoner… middleclass stoner kid, you know.
Like, too cool for school, too cool to care.
I thought I didn't give a fuck, you know,
translation.ko: 전 제가 신경을 끈 줄 알았는데

translation.en: but it's like I actually gave way too many fucks.
And that's why I was scared to really do anything.
And when he died, it was a wake up call of like,
translation.ko: 그래서 뭐든 도전하는 게 두려웠는데 조시가 죽었을 때 정신이 번뜩 들더라고요

translation.en: "Dude… you've got to care. You've got to pick something and care."
translation.ko: '인마, 신경 좀 써라 뭔가에 관심을 가져야지'

translation.en: 'Cause it can be gone… any moment.
It doesn't matter how old you are, doesn't matter how…
how fit you are, or whatever, like…
It can… When it goes, it goes fast,
translation.ko: 눈 깜빡할 사이에 사라질 수 있어요

translation.en: and… nobody is prepared for it.
translation.ko: 하지만 그 누구도 죽음에 대비하지 못하죠

translation.en: When I… when I think about Josh, I-I just… I think he'd be proud of me.
translation.ko: 조시도 저를 대견하게 여길 것 같아요

translation.en: I think he kind of felt like an older brother to me too, you know?
I think he kind of saw that I needed to be pushed.
translation.ko: 제 등을 떠밀어야 한다는 걸 조시는 알았나 봐요

translation.en: And he was that friend who pushed me.
translation.ko: 그 친구가 제 등을 떠밀어 줬죠

translation.en: He would fucking love this.
He would love every second of it.
I have this weird tendency whenever I visit someplace…
translation.ko: 전 이상한 버릇이 있는데요 어디든 높은 곳에 올라가면

translation.en: high.
I want to stand as close to the edge as possible.
translation.ko: 끝자락에 최대한 가까이 서 보려고 해요

translation.en: There's kind of like this unconscious awareness your body has
translation.ko: 목숨을 잃을 수도 있는 벼랑 끝에 서면

translation.en: whenever you're close to an edge that could kill you.
And as soon as you're within, you know, say ten feet, that…
your body is in alert status.
It just kind of… it sends this jolt of anxiety through you.
And then you're forced to confront that anxiety,
and then you take another step.
And each step, the anxiety just start compounding
to the point where your hands are shaking,
your scalp is sweating,
your brain starts flashing…
visions of it all ending.
That's what I find when I get close to a cliff edge.
translation.ko: 벼랑 끝에 서면 그런 깨달음을 얻어요

translation.en: It brings me back to that place of pure thankfulness for being alive.
translation.ko: 살아 있다는 사실에 다시금 마냥 감사하게 되죠

translation.en: But there's really only a few things in life that are ever worth giving a fuck about.
translation.ko: 근데 살면서 신경 쓸 만한 건 사실 얼마 안 되거든요

translation.en: Only in the face of death,
all of the superficial and bullshitty values that we buy into
start to fall away.
You start to realize that that the dumb status games you play no longer mean anything.
translation.ko: 한심한 서열 놀이 따위는 무의미하다는 걸 깨닫게 되죠

translation.en: Or that the achievements and accolades that you struggled for so many years for,
translation.ko: 오랫동안 애쓴 끝에 이룬 업적과 영예도

translation.en: nobody cares about when you're gone.
When we avoid the question of death,
that's when we get highjacked by silly and superficial and hateful ideas.
It's when we become certain in ourselves, even though we have no clue what's going on.
translation.ko: 그럼 뭐가 뭔지도 모르면서 본인에 대한 확신만 늘죠

translation.en: The gravity of our entitlement pulls all of our attention inwards,
translation.ko: 특권 의식이 중력처럼 모든 관심을 내면으로 빨아들여서

translation.en: to become obsessed with our problems, to convince ourselves
translation.ko: 자기 문제에만 집착하고 내 문제가 이 우주의 중심이라고 느끼게 돼요

translation.en: that our problems are somehow at the center of the universe,
translation.ko: 내 문제가 이 우주의 중심이라고 느끼게 돼요

translation.en: that we are at the center of all injustices,
that we are the ones who are destined for greatness,
that we are the ones who deserve something over others.
translation.ko: 나는 남보다 더 많이 누려야 한다고 믿죠

translation.en: Without acknowledging the ever-present gaze of death,
translation.ko: 시종일관 우리를 노리는 죽음의 존재를 인정하지 않으면

translation.en: the superficial begins to feel important,
and the important starts to feel superficial.
Thinking about death removes all that.
translation.ko: 죽음을 떠올리면 그 모든 게 사라져요

translation.en: It forces you to see
that 99 percent of the shit going on in your day-to-day life
translation.ko: 그럼 깨닫게 되죠 일상에서 겪는 99%의 문제가

translation.en: doesn't fucking matter.
Death is the only certainty in life.
Therefore death must be the compass
by which we orient all of our values and decisions.
How are you using your time?
How are you using your limited fucks?
Who are you going to be with?
This constant remembering of my own mortality,
translation.ko: 언젠가 찾아올 내 죽음을 끊임없이 되새기는 건

translation.en: for me, it's the most effective tool for unraveling everything.
translation.ko: 모든 문제를 해결하는 가장 유용한 방식일 거예요

translation.en: My sense of entitlement, my closed-up identity,
translation.ko: 나의 특권 의식과 꽉 막힌 정체성과

translation.en: my irrational certainties.
By remembering that it's all a bunch of dust that will soon be gone…
translation.ko: 그 모든 게 곧 사라질 먼지에 불과하다는 걸 명심하면

translation.en: …it's easier to let go.
It's this ability to choose ourselves
in an endless ambiguity that makes us great.
translation.ko: 끝없는 불확실성 속에서 스스로 선택하는 능력 덕분이죠

translation.en: You don't have to go do something to feel these things.
translation.ko: 그건 뭘 해내야만 느낄 수 있는 게 아닙니다

translation.en: You don't have to go be something to realize these things.
translation.ko: 어떤 존재가 되어야만 깨달을 수 있는 것도 아니고요

translation.en: You simply are them.
The more I think about my own death, the brighter life gets.
translation.ko: 자신의 죽음을 떠올릴수록 남은 인생이 더 빛나죠

translation.en: The quieter the world becomes.
The easier decisions become.
You, too, are going to die one day,
but that's because you are fortunate enough to have lived.
translation.ko: 그건 삶이란 행운을 누리고 있기 때문이에요

translation.en: And you may not feel this right now. You may not feel any of this.
translation.ko: 당장은 이런 얘기에 전혀 공감 못 하시더라도

translation.en: But go stand on a cliff sometime and maybe you will.
translation.ko: 언젠가 벼랑 끝에 서 보면 느끼실지도 몰라요
